project_metadata.paper_title: Creating large, high-quality geospatial datasets from historical maps using novice volunteers
project_metadata.research_context: The Tundzha Regional Archaeological Project (TRAP) in Bulgaria used a customized mobile application (FAIMS Mobile) for crowdsourced digitization of burial mounds from Soviet military topographic maps during 2017-2018 archaeological fieldwork.

prior_work.trap_previous_mound_survey: Between 2008 and 2016, TRAP catalogued 773 mounds in Kazanlak Valley and 431 mounds in Yambol region using pedestrian surface survey supported by manual digitisation of satellite imagery and maps
prior_work.faims_mobile_prior_use: FAIMS Mobile had previously been used with some success for a student-led ceramics recording project (VanValkenburgh et al., 2018) and improved recording efficiency in other settings (Sobotkova et al., 2016)

study_area_characteristics.map_coverage: Each Soviet topographic map (1:50,000 scale, 1980s) covers ca 400 sq km
study_area_characteristics.feature_density: Symbols occurred at high density, averaging about 200 per tile (0.5 per sq km), with counts per tile ranging from about 50 to 400
study_area_characteristics.estimated_yambol_features: Maps of the Yambol region contained 1,000+ targeted symbols

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS Mobile was used to digitise 10,827 mound features from Soviet military topographic maps
evidence.verbatim_quote: FAIMS Mobile was used to digitise 10,827 mound features from Soviet military topographic maps.

evidence.evidence_text: Digitisation required 241 person-hours total (57 from staff; 184 from novice volunteers)
evidence.verbatim_quote: This digitisation required 241 person-hours (57 from staff; 184 from novice volunteers), with an error rate under 6%.

evidence.evidence_text: Error rate was under 6%
evidence.verbatim_quote: This digitisation required 241 person-hours (57 from staff; 184 from novice volunteers), with an error rate under 6%.

evidence.evidence_text: The resulting dataset was consistent, well-documented, and ready for analysis with a few hours of processing
evidence.verbatim_quote: The resulting dataset was consistent, well-documented, and ready for analysis with a few hours of processing.

evidence.evidence_text: Deployment in Bulgaria as an ancillary activity during 2017–2018 archaeological fieldwork
evidence.verbatim_quote: Deployed in Bulgaria as an ancillary activity during 2017–2018 archaeological fieldwork, FAIMS Mobile was used to digitise 10,827 mound features from Soviet military topographic maps.

evidence.evidence_text: An estimated 50,000 burial mounds were built in Bulgarian lands from the Early Bronze Age through the Middle Ages
evidence.verbatim_quote: An estimated 50,000 burial mounds were built in Bulgarian lands from the Early Bronze Age through the Middle Ages (Shkorpil & Shkorpil, 1989, p. 20; Kitov, 1993, p. 42).

evidence.evidence_text: Mounds range in size from 10 to 50 m in diameter and 0.5–20 m in height
evidence.verbatim_quote: They were constructed of earth and rubble, and range in size from 10 to 50 m in diameter and 0.5–20 m in height (see Fig. 1).

evidence.evidence_text: Records were relatively simple: a point for the feature, a record number, plus ten attributes

location.section: 2.1 Archaeological features in Soviet topographic maps

evidence.verbatim_quote: The records we sought to create were relatively simple: a point for the feature, a record number, plus ten attributes.

evidence.evidence_text: Students came from a range of academic backgrounds in Arts and Humanities, with most having no training in archaeology, cartography, or digital methods
evidence.verbatim_quote: Our students came from a range of academic backgrounds in Arts and Humanities. Most had no training in archaeology, cartography, or digital methods (unlike Podőr, 2015 or Can et al., 2021).

evidence.evidence_text: In 2010, volunteer attrition combined with demands on staff time during the height of fieldwork rendered the desktop GIS approach unsuccessful
evidence.verbatim_quote: In the end, volunteer attrition combined with demands on staff time during the height of fieldwork rendered this approach unsuccessful.

evidence.evidence_text: Students found learning to configure and navigate desktop GIS challenging; many quit and those who continued required ongoing support
evidence.verbatim_quote: Our experience was much like that of other projects: novice volunteers found learning to configure and navigate desktop GIS challenging; many quit and those who continued required ongoing support.

evidence.evidence_text: Only two of 12 students brought computers, and none brought mice, but all had mobile devices

location.section: 2.3 Using a mobile application for map digitisation

evidence.verbatim_quote: This choice also reduced competition for the limited number of computers, ESRI licences, and desk space available in the field, plus it allowed students to use their own devices (only two of 12 students brought computers, and none brought mice, but all had mobile devices).

evidence.evidence_text: System customisation and setup across both seasons required 51 h total (36 h from programmer, 15 h from staff), with initial customisation requiring 39 h (35 h programmer + 4 h staff)

location.section: 3.1 Project staff time for setup, support, and accuracy-checking

evidence.verbatim_quote: For the first season of use (2017), creating the Map Digitisation customisation of FAIMS Mobile required 35 h from an undergraduate student programmer plus 4 h from staff (Nassif-Haynes et al., 2021). [...] Across both seasons, customisation, setup, and supervision took about 51 h, including 36 h from the programmer and 15 from project staff.

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Both items support identical claims (C002, C003, C031) and are never cited independently. Combined to show total customisation time with breakdown.

evidence.evidence_text: In-field setup and map distribution required 7 h of staff time across both seasons (44 h pre-field customisation, 7 h in-field preparation and supervision)

location.section: 3.1 Project staff time for setup, support, and accuracy-checking

evidence.verbatim_quote: Setup of the server and configuration of the client devices in the field required 3 h from staff. [...] Of this time, initial customisation and setup time before fieldwork was 44 h, while the time required during fieldwork to prepare and distribute maps, and then supervise participants, was 7 h.

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Both items support identical claims (C002, C031) and are never cited independently. Combined to show temporal breakdown of staff time.

evidence.evidence_text: Map preparation (tiling, adding pyramids) required about 1.5 h (2017)

location.section: 3.1 Project staff time for setup, support, and accuracy-checking

evidence.verbatim_quote: Map preparation (tiling, adding pyramids) required about 1.5 h.

evidence.evidence_text: Training and supervision of students took no more than half an hour of staff time across the entire season (2017)

location.section: 3.1 Project staff time for setup, support, and accuracy-checking

evidence.verbatim_quote: Training and supervision of students took no more than half an hour of staff time across the entire season.

evidence.evidence_text: Re-examination of four randomly selected maps after fieldwork required 6 h of staff time

location.section: 3.1 Project staff time for setup, support, and accuracy-checking

evidence.verbatim_quote: Finally, re-examination of four randomly selected maps after fieldwork required 6 h of staff time, including desktop GIS setup, confirmation of feature digitisation, and tabulating errors and error rates.

evidence.evidence_text: In 2017, the system was used for 125.8 person-hours, during which time 8,343 features were digitised from 42 Soviet topographic maps (ca. 17,000 sq km)
evidence.verbatim_quote: In 2017, it was used for a total of 125.8 person-hours concentrated across five rainy days, during which time 8,343 features were digitised from 42 Soviet topographic maps (ca. 17,000 sq km).

evidence.evidence_text: The average time to record a point feature in 2017 was 54 s
evidence.verbatim_quote: The average time to record a point feature was 54 s, based on start and end times of feature creation as recorded by the devices (representing work time excluding pauses between records).

evidence.evidence_text: In 2018, the system was used for 63.6 person-hours, with 2,484 features recorded from 16 maps (ca. 6,500 sq km), at an average rate of one record every 92 s
evidence.verbatim_quote: The system was used for 63.6 person-hours, with 2,484 features recorded from 16 maps (ca. 6,500 sq km), an average rate of one record every 92 s.

evidence.evidence_text: In total, 10,827 point features were recorded in 189.4 student-hours (63 s per record)
evidence.verbatim_quote: In total, 10,827 point features, mostly burial and settlement mounds, were recorded in 189.4 student-hours (63 s per record).

evidence.evidence_text: The dataset contained as many as 119,097 discrete values (single point record could be associated with 11 attribute-value pairs, many captured automatically)
evidence.verbatim_quote: Since a single point record could be associated with 11 attribute-value pairs, the dataset contained as many as 119,097 discrete values (many captured automatically).

evidence.evidence_text: In 2010, desktop GIS digitisation effort produced a dataset of 915 features and required about 5–7 h of staff training, support, and error-checking over a three-week period
evidence.verbatim_quote: Although we did not maintain detailed volunteer time-on-task records, we know this effort produced a dataset of 915 features and required about 5–7 h of staff training, support, and error-checking over a three-week period (based on our field journals).

evidence.evidence_text: One persistent student accounted for almost all the desktop GIS digitised features; without his perseverance, the digitisation effort would have failed entirely
evidence.verbatim_quote: Indeed, one persistent student accounted for almost all the digitised features; without his perseverance, the digitisation effort would have failed entirely.

evidence.evidence_text: Recoverable data omissions across both years totaled 223 (2.06% of records), including 205 spatial and 18 attribute omissions

location.section: 3.5.1 Recoverable data omissions and incomplete records

evidence.verbatim_quote: Recoverable data omissions across both years totaled 223 (2.06% of records), including 205 spatial and 18 attribute omissions.

evidence.evidence_text: Review of four randomly selected maps found 49 errors from a true count of 834 features, a 5.87% error rate
evidence.verbatim_quote: Second, a review by project staff of four randomly selected maps (7% of the total) found 49 errors from a true count of 834 features, a 5.87% error rate (see Table 3).

evidence.evidence_text: Forty-two of the 49 errors were false negatives (symbols missed by students), six were double-marked, one was a classification error, and zero were false positives
evidence.verbatim_quote: Forty-two of these errors were false negatives (symbols missed by students). Six were double-marked (Student C digitised a section of a map twice). Students made only one classification error (a similar symbol mistaken for a benchmark), and no outright false positives.

evidence.evidence_text: Individual student error rates ranged from 1.3% to 10.6%
evidence.verbatim_quote: Students' individual error rates ranged from 1.3% to 10.6%.

evidence.evidence_text: The two fastest digitisers (Students A and B; 44 and 45 s per feature) also had the lowest error rates (1.3 and 2.9%), while the two slowest (Students C and D; 61 and 73 s) had the highest error rates (10.6 and 7.4%)
evidence.verbatim_quote: Note that the two fastest digitisers (Students A and B; 44 and 45 s per feature respectively) also had the lowest error rates (1.3 and 2.9%), while the two slowest (Students C and D; 61 and 73 s) had the highest error rates (10.6 and 7.4%).

evidence.evidence_text: Project staff with desktop GIS experience could digitise at a sustained rate of 60–75 features per staff-hour
evidence.verbatim_quote: After brief workspace setup, project staff with desktop GIS experience could digitise at a sustained rate of 60–75 features per staff-hour.

evidence.evidence_text: Based on 2010 digitisation rate, desktop GIS with novice volunteers produced 130–180 features per staff-hour
evidence.verbatim_quote: Had specialist project staff instead trained and supervised volunteers to use desktop GIS for digitisation, based on our 2010 digitisation rate of 130–180 features per staff-hour, 57 h might have produced 7,410–10,260 features.

evidence.evidence_text: The 57 h of staff time required for the crowdsourcing system produced 10,827 features, or about 190 features per staff-hour
evidence.verbatim_quote: By comparison, the 57 h of staff time required for our digitisation approach using a customisation of FAIMS Mobile produced 10,827 features, or about 190 features per staff-hour.

evidence.evidence_text: The Urban Occupations Project reported 1,250 h of manual digitisation to create training data, with an ML expert spending seven days testing and fine tuning the model, digitising approximately 300,000 km of roads
evidence.verbatim_quote: This project reported 1,250 h of manual digitisation to create enough training data to classify roads visible in historical maps of the Ottoman Empire. Using this input, and after additional preprocessing and filtering, an ML expert spent seven days testing and fine tuning the model. The output was impressive: some 300,000 km of roads were digitised.

claims.claim_text: The crowdsourcing approach produced a large, accurate, analysis-ready dataset
claims.verbatim_quote: The resulting dataset was consistent, well-documented, and ready for analysis with a few hours of processing.

claims.claim_text: The crowdsourcing approach required little training or supervision of students, used open-source software and low-cost equipment
claims.verbatim_quote: Compared to manual digitisation approaches based on desktop GIS, it required little training or supervision of students, used open-source software and low-cost equipment, yet produced a large, accurate, analysis-ready dataset.

claims.claim_text: The crowdsourcing approach is most efficient for digitisation projects of 10,000–60,000 features, but may offer advantages for datasets as small as a few hundred records

declared_uncertainty.author_explanation: Based on comparative analysis with other approaches

claims.verbatim_quote: A conservative estimate based on our work suggests our crowdsourcing approach is most efficient for digitisation projects of 10,000–60,000 features, but may offer advantages for datasets as small as a few hundred records.

claims.claim_text: Systems designed for field data collection, running on mobile devices, can be profitably customised to serve as participatory geospatial data systems accessible to novice volunteers
claims.verbatim_quote: Furthermore, it indicates that systems designed for field data collection, running on mobile devices, can be profitably customised to serve as participatory geospatial data systems accessible to novice volunteers.

claims.claim_text: The approach complements Machine Learning and other automated approaches by requiring less technical expertise, time, and resourcing
claims.verbatim_quote: It complements Machine Learning (ML) and other automated approaches in that it requires less technical expertise, time, and resourcing to undertake.

claims.claim_text: Unlocking data from historical maps for landscape analysis is costly
claims.verbatim_quote: Unlocking data from historical maps for landscape analysis is costly.

claims.claim_text: Automatic extraction using Machine Learning requires extensive preparation and expertise
claims.verbatim_quote: Automatic extraction using Machine Learning (ML) requires extensive preparation and expertise.

claims.claim_text: Crowdsourcing scales better than direct digitisation by experts, but requires an appropriate platform and the technical skills to adapt it
claims.verbatim_quote: Crowdsourcing scales better than direct digitisation by experts, but requires an appropriate platform and the technical skills to adapt it.

claims.claim_text: Burial mounds are an irreplaceable but endangered aspect of Bulgarian cultural heritage, making their systematic recording and registration an urgent undertaking
claims.verbatim_quote: Burial mounds are an irreplaceable - but endangered - aspect of Bulgarian cultural heritage, making their systematic recording and registration an urgent undertaking for both research and cultural heritage management.

claims.claim_text: Existing research provides little guidance as to when investments in these approaches become worthwhile
claims.verbatim_quote: Existing research provides little guidance as to when investments in these approaches become worthwhile.

claims.claim_text: Historical maps constitute an important source of information for historical landscapes and the cultural heritage they contain
claims.verbatim_quote: Historical maps constitute an important source of information for historical landscapes and the cultural heritage they contain.

claims.claim_text: The value of historical maps has been underexploited due to the entailed process of manual digitisation needed to transform their analogue information into machine-readable data
claims.verbatim_quote: The value of such maps has, however, been underexploited due to the entailed process of manual digitisation needed to transform their analogue information into machine-readable data.

claims.claim_text: Manually drawing and annotating shapes in historical maps using a desktop GIS is time-consuming and requires specialised skills
claims.verbatim_quote: Manually drawing and annotating shapes in historical maps using a desktop GIS is time-consuming and requires specialised skills (Can, Gerrits, and Kabadayi 2021; Petrie et al., 2018; Jones & Weber, 2012).

claims.claim_text: The principal limitations of manual desktop GIS digitisation are difficulty of scaling the effort, particularly restricted time and availability of expert users
claims.verbatim_quote: Its principal limitations are difficulty of scaling the effort, particularly restricted time and availability of expert users to either undertake digitisation themselves, or to train and support novices to the extent required for efficient and accurate work (see also Jessop, 2007 for other challenges).

claims.claim_text: Machine Learning has unmatched potential for large-scale data digitisation
claims.verbatim_quote: ML has unmatched potential for large-scale data digitisation, but it requires specific programming expertise, and familiarity with the capabilities and limitations of ML.

claims.claim_text: Machine Learning requires specific programming expertise, and familiarity with the capabilities and limitations of ML
claims.verbatim_quote: ML has unmatched potential for large-scale data digitisation, but it requires specific programming expertise, and familiarity with the capabilities and limitations of ML.

claims.claim_text: Naive use of ML is likely to produce biased or otherwise unreliable results
claims.verbatim_quote: Naive use of ML is likely to produce biased or otherwise unreliable results (Mehrabi et al., 2021; Schwemmer et al., 2020; Besse et al., 2018; Fuchs, 2018; Haas, 2017), even if pretrained image recognition models are used (Jiang et al., 2022).

claims.claim_text: Training an ML algorithm requires manual creation and preparation of training data and manual quality assurance
claims.verbatim_quote: Training an algorithm, moreover, requires manual creation and preparation of training data and manual quality assurance (Bennett et al., 2014; Can & Kabadayi, 2021).

claims.claim_text: The expertise necessary to use a GIS has hindered collaboration between specialists and the broader community in the past

location.section: 1.4 Sociotechnical barriers to collaborative map digitisation

claims.verbatim_quote: The expertise necessary to use a GIS has hindered collaboration between specialists and the broader community in the past (Jessop, 2007, p. 43).

claims.claim_text: Producing and manipulating geospatial data challenges novice users more than other data tasks

location.section: 1.4 Sociotechnical barriers to collaborative map digitisation

claims.verbatim_quote: Producing and manipulating geospatial data, even if it is limited to 'simple' activities like symbol digitisation (Goodchild, 2007), challenges novice users more than other data tasks.

claims.claim_text: Volunteers often lack the skills necessary to use GIS software

location.section: 1.4 Sociotechnical barriers to collaborative map digitisation

claims.verbatim_quote: Volunteers often lack the skills necessary to use GIS software (Elwood, 2008b; Jones & Weber, 2012; Owen et al., 2009).

claims.claim_text: The 'digital divide' in GIS skills can be bridged in part through more expert training and guidance of novice users

location.section: 1.4 Sociotechnical barriers to collaborative map digitisation

claims.verbatim_quote: This 'digital divide' can be bridged in part through more expert training and guidance of novice users (Owen et al., 2009, p. 24).

claims.claim_text: Expert training and guidance for volunteers scales poorly due to restricted expert time and limited volunteer willingness to learn specialized skills

location.section: 1.4 Sociotechnical barriers to collaborative map digitisation

claims.verbatim_quote: Such an approach scales poorly, however; the supply of expert time available to any project is restricted and often oversubscribed, while the willingness of volunteers to learn specialised skills and software has limits.

claims.claim_text: Expert interaction with volunteers can be profitably supplemented by the development of 'useful' tools that combine 'utility' with 'usability'

location.section: 1.4 Sociotechnical barriers to collaborative map digitisation

claims.verbatim_quote: While some expert interaction is unavoidable and desirable, it can be profitably supplemented by the development of 'useful' tools that combine 'utility' with 'usability' (Nielsen, 2012).

claims.claim_text: The digitisation interface was streamlined, stripping GIS functionality to its essentials and focusing on three tasks: layer selection, shape digitisation, and annotation
claims.verbatim_quote: As such, it stripped GIS functionality to its essentials, focusing on three tasks: layer selection, shape digitisation, and annotation, with validation and automation to improve data quality.

claims.claim_text: The approach sought to help novice users begin digitising quickly and then work productively with minimal support or frustration
claims.verbatim_quote: Our approach sought to help novice users begin digitising quickly and then work productively for the duration of each field season with minimal support or frustration.

claims.claim_text: TRAP staff never had the time to undertake large-scale map digitisation work themselves
claims.verbatim_quote: TRAP staff never had the time to undertake large-scale map digitisation work themselves.

claims.claim_text: In 2017, faced with a short field season and little time for student training, the project focused on implementing tools that would empower volunteers to digitise maps independently
claims.verbatim_quote: In 2017, faced with a short field season and little time for student training, we focused on implementing tools that would empower volunteers to digitise maps independently.

claims.claim_text: The use of mobile devices reduced competition for limited computers and allowed students to use their own devices

location.section: 2.3 Using a mobile application for map digitisation

claims.verbatim_quote: This choice also reduced competition for the limited number of computers, ESRI licences, and desk space available in the field, plus it allowed students to use their own devices (only two of 12 students brought computers, and none brought mice, but all had mobile devices).

claims.claim_text: No existing system met the requirements 'off-the-shelf' without significant customisation, and no competing product offered enough of an advantage to justify adopting a second geospatial recording system

location.section: 2.3 Using a mobile application for map digitisation

claims.verbatim_quote: No existing system met these requirements 'off-the-shelf', without significant customisation, and no competing product offered enough of an advantage to justify adopting a second geospatial recording system.

claims.claim_text: The crowdsourcing system required modest upfront investment but minimal ongoing staff time

location.section: 3.1 Project staff time for setup, support, and accuracy-checking

claims.verbatim_quote: Of this time, initial customisation and setup time before fieldwork was 44 h, while the time required during fieldwork to prepare and distribute maps, and then supervise participants, was 7 h.

claims.claim_text: The streamlined system allowed volunteers to begin work with minimal training and help them resume work after any hiatus
claims.verbatim_quote: It also benefited from the UI/UX approach employed for kinetic fieldwork (e.g., Pascoe et al., 2000). The principle that the technology had to conform to the workflow, rather than vice versa, translated particularly well to map digitisation. The result was a simple, familiar mobile application interface that let novices begin work with little training and helped them resume work after any hiatus.

claims.claim_text: Volunteers could attain a high rate of digitisation quickly and maintain it
claims.verbatim_quote: Volunteers could attain a high rate of digitisation quickly and maintain it, although further design refinement could improve the ability of more experienced users to enter data even more quickly (for an example of an optimised system in another domain, see Noble et al., 2020, 2018).

claims.claim_text: Desktop GIS approach had high cognitive load on novice users
claims.verbatim_quote: These problems reflect the high cognitive load desktop GIS places on novice users.

claims.claim_text: The customised application met fundamental usability requirements through careful design and implementation of UI/UX principles
claims.verbatim_quote: By contrast, our customised application met fundamental usability requirements (e.g., Nielsen, 2012), both due to careful design of the customisation itself, and the underlying platform's implementation of Google's Material Design guidelines.

claims.claim_text: Overall accuracy was high, over 94% for processed maps
claims.verbatim_quote: Unlike some volunteer digitisation projects, overall accuracy was high, over 94% for processed maps.

claims.claim_text: The pattern of errors (mostly false negatives and double-marked features from contiguous map sections) made them relatively easy to identify and correct
claims.verbatim_quote: Nevertheless, the overall rate of 5.9% exceeded our expectations. Moreover, the pattern of errors - mostly false negatives and double-marked features, mostly from contiguous map sections - made them relatively easy to identify and correct.

claims.claim_text: The best digitisers could be both fast and accurate, while the poorest digitisers were often neither fast nor accurate
claims.verbatim_quote: The best digitisers, furthermore, could be both fast and accurate, while the poorest digitisers were often neither fast nor accurate (see Tables 1–3).

claims.claim_text: The crowdsourcing approach becomes worthwhile for datasets no larger than about 4,500 features versus direct digitisation by expert staff, and no larger than about 10,000 features versus volunteer digitisation using desktop GIS

declared_uncertainty.author_explanation: Based on time comparisons with specific qualifications about context

claims.verbatim_quote: To summarise in round numbers, a crowdsourcing approach like ours is most suitable for datasets numbering perhaps 10,000–60,000 records, assuming similar feature characteristics and data collection requirements (see Table 5). Below 10,000 records, approaches using desktop GIS should be considered.

claims.claim_text: Above 60,000 records, ML approaches should be contemplated, but only if a project has access to the requisite expertise
claims.verbatim_quote: Above 60,000 records, ML approaches should be contemplated, but only if a project has access to the requisite expertise.

claims.claim_text: A dataset big enough to justify ML will likely need a training dataset big enough to warrant crowdsourcing
claims.verbatim_quote: A dataset big enough to justify ML will likely need a training dataset big enough to warrant crowdsourcing, especially if the features or background are variable.

claims.claim_text: Crowdsourcing and ML approaches are not exclusive, but complementary
claims.verbatim_quote: The approaches are not exclusive, therefore, but complementary.

claims.claim_text: A typical project in history or archaeology may not be able to dedicate the personnel, infrastructure, or attention needed to incorporate ML successfully, but could deploy a collaborative geospatial system for crowdsourcing map digitisation
claims.verbatim_quote: Today, a typical project in history or archaeology - often small, under-resourced, and pursuing several research activities - may not be able to dedicate the personnel, infrastructure, or attention needed to incorporate ML successfully, but could deploy a collaborative geospatial system for crowdsourcing map digitisation.

claims.claim_text: Deploying a crowdsourcing system requires a higher up-front investment in time and expertise than use of desktop GIS approaches, but it is feasible
claims.verbatim_quote: Deploying such a system requires a higher up-front investment in time and expertise than use of desktop GIS approaches, but it is feasible.

claims.claim_text: The approach is readily transferable to other mobile GIS systems and map corpora
claims.verbatim_quote: This approach is readily transferable to other mobile GIS systems and map corpora, but our experience provides only a single data point for assessing the applicability of various digitisation approaches to historical maps.

claims.claim_text: More projects need to track and publish time, error rates, feature characteristics, and complexity to refine and generalise the recommendations
claims.verbatim_quote: More projects - whether they use manual or automated approaches - need to track and publish the expert and volunteer time required for setup, training, support, and quality assurance related to map digitisation, as well as digitisation speed, error rates and types, the characteristics of the features being digitised, and the complexity of information extracted. More such data could refine and generalise the recommendations proposed here.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: The quality of volunteer-digitised data from novices can match or exceed expert-digitised data when appropriate tools and workflows are used
trigger_text: Compared to manual digitisation approaches based on desktop GIS, it required little training or supervision of students, used open-source software and low-cost equipment, yet produced a large, accurate, analysis-ready dataset.
The resulting dataset was consistent, well-documented, and ready for analysis with a few hours of processing.
Overall accuracy was high, over 94% for processed maps.
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The authors present evidence that novices produced high-quality data (>94% accuracy, analysis-ready) with minimal supervision. This implies but doesn't explicitly state that appropriate tool design can enable novices to produce expert-quality work, bridging the gap between 'novice volunteers' and 'high quality dataset'.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: The technical complexity of GIS tasks can be hidden from users through appropriate interface design without sacrificing functionality
trigger_text: As such, it stripped GIS functionality to its essentials, focusing on three tasks: layer selection, shape digitisation, and annotation, with validation and automation to improve data quality.
Students capable of selecting files from a list, panning and zooming a map, dropping a point, and filling out a form were able to create data.
Geospatial data preparation and management was relegated to staff, while a simple and intuitive UI allowed students to begin digitising after only minutes of training.

trigger_locations.section: 2.4 Design and implementation of the recording system
2.4 Design and implementation of the recording system

implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The authors describe stripping GIS to essentials and relegating complex tasks to staff, but don't explicitly state the underlying assumption that technical complexity can be separated from user-facing tasks. This is a key design principle in HCI but isn't articulated as such in the paper.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Staff time is the primary constraint for digitisation projects, more so than volunteer time or equipment costs
trigger_text: This discussion, furthermore, focuses on our most limited resource: staff time. As such, the calculations below, which propose dataset size thresholds for various approaches, prioritise staff time required for digitisation.
Projects where staff time is at a premium, or that operate alongside fieldwork where staff have many competing demands, may find it valuable for smaller datasets (even those below 1,000 records).
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The entire comparative analysis prioritizes staff time over other metrics (total person-hours, equipment costs, etc.). This assumption that staff time is the primary constraint is stated once but underpins the entire threshold calculation. It's an economic assumption about relative resource scarcity.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Mobile devices reduce barriers to participation by leveraging existing user familiarity and personal equipment
trigger_text: student volunteers are accustomed to, and even prefer, 'slippy-map', touch-screen interfaces on mobile devices over the point-and-click, desktop UI idiom.

This choice also reduced competition for the limited number of computers, ESRI licences, and desk space available in the field, plus it allowed students to use their own devices (only two of 12 students brought computers, and none brought mice, but all had mobile devices).

trigger_locations.section: 2.3 Using a mobile application for map digitisation
2.3 Using a mobile application for map digitisation

implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The authors note that students prefer mobile interfaces and all had mobile devices, but don't explicitly connect this to the broader claim about participatory systems being 'accessible to novice volunteers.' The bridging claim connects device familiarity to accessibility.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: For small to mid-sized projects, access to ML expertise is a more significant barrier than the time required for manual digitisation
trigger_text: This technical expertise is in high demand, and may be difficult to attract to the smaller humanities and social sciences (HASS) projects that undertake much of this digitisation.

Today, a typical project in history or archaeology - often small, under-resourced, and pursuing several research activities - may not be able to dedicate the personnel, infrastructure, or attention needed to incorporate ML successfully
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The claim that crowdsourcing 'complements' ML assumes that typical projects can't access ML expertise even when dataset size would justify it. This assumption about relative accessibility of different forms of expertise is implicit in the comparative assessment.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: The thresholds are generalizable despite being based on a single case study with specific feature characteristics
trigger_text: A conservative estimate based on our work suggests our crowdsourcing approach is most efficient for digitisation projects of 10,000–60,000 features

To summarise in round numbers, a crowdsourcing approach like ours is most suitable for datasets numbering perhaps 10,000–60,000 records, assuming similar feature characteristics and data collection requirements
our experience provides only a single data point for assessing the applicability of various digitisation approaches to historical maps
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The authors provide specific thresholds but also acknowledge this is based on one case. The implicit assumption is that the key variables (feature density, complexity, symbol obtrusiveness) are similar enough across map digitisation projects to allow generalization, despite explicitly noting this limitation.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: The manual effort required for ML training data is substantial enough to constitute a digitisation project in its own right
trigger_text: This project reported 1,250 h of manual digitisation to create enough training data to classify roads visible in historical maps of the Ottoman Empire.
Training an algorithm, moreover, requires manual creation and preparation of training data and manual quality assurance
A dataset big enough to justify ML will likely need a training dataset big enough to warrant crowdsourcing
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: If 1,250 hours were required for training data (more than the 241 hours in this entire project), then creating ML training data is itself a major digitisation undertaking. This implies that crowdsourcing could be used for that training data creation, making the approaches complementary rather than alternatives.

research_designs.design_text: Case study research design evaluating crowdsourced map digitization approach
research_designs.verbatim_quote: This article presents a case study of crowdsourced cultural heritage digitisation from historical maps undertaken by volunteers using a lightweight, streamlined Geographical Information System (GIS) running offline on mobile devices.

indicators: Case study approach with pattern discovery from empirical work

research_designs.design_text: Comparative evaluation design to assess digitization approach efficiency thresholds
research_designs.verbatim_quote: At that point, we decided to catalogue inputs (time invested by staff and volunteers) versus outputs (features digitised) as part of a research program to evaluate digital approaches to fieldwork (e.g., Sobotkova et al., 2016).

indicators: Explicit hypothesis about when approach becomes worthwhile

methods.method_text: Crowdsourced map digitization using customized mobile GIS platform (FAIMS Mobile)
methods.verbatim_quote: For the 2017–2018 field seasons, TRAP staff created a simplified and streamlined data capture system built using the FAIMS Mobile platform. This system allowed any number of participants to digitise map features using mobile devices, regardless of network connectivity, and consolidated the resulting data when a network became available.

methods.method_text: Participant recruitment via archaeological field school - novice volunteers with no prior GIS training
methods.verbatim_quote: The task of digitising potentially thousands of mounds provided an opportunity to involve students in authentic research. Our students came from a range of academic backgrounds in Arts and Humanities. Most had no training in archaeology, cartography, or digital methods (unlike Pödör, 2015 or Can et al., 2021).

sampling_strategy.participant_characteristics: Arts and Humanities students with no GIS training

methods.method_text: Map symbol extraction targeting archaeological features from Soviet topographic maps
methods.verbatim_quote: The goal of the work was to extract archaeological features from 1:50,000 scale Soviet military topographic maps dating to the 1980s. Available as georeferenced GeoTIFFs (from http://web.uni-plovdiv.bg/vedrin/index_en.html in 2008), each of these maps covers ca 400 sq km. We wished to extract symbols from them that might represent burial or settlement mounds in our study area (see Fig. 2).

location.section: 2.1 Archaeological features in Soviet topographic maps

methods.method_text: Time-on-task measurement for staff and volunteers across all workflow stages
methods.verbatim_quote: To measure inputs, we collated the amount of time spent by various participants in the process, including the student programmer who instantiated the customisation, the student volunteers who undertook the digitisation, and project staff who configured the system, supported volunteers, exported data, and checked for errors. Project records provided much of this data (timesheets from the programmer; record creation timestamps for students using the system), while project staff logged time-on-task for activities in journals.

methods.method_text: Random sampling of digitized maps for accuracy assessment
methods.verbatim_quote: Finally, project staff reviewed randomly selected digitisation work completed by volunteers to characterise errors.

methods.method_text: Desktop GIS digitization baseline comparison (2010 season)
methods.verbatim_quote: To overcome this problem, in 2010, project staff worked with student volunteers to digitise map features using ArcGIS. Our experience was much like that of other projects: novice volunteers found learning to configure and navigate desktop GIS challenging; many quit and those who continued required ongoing support. In the end, volunteer attrition combined with demands on staff time during the height of fieldwork rendered this approach unsuccessful.

methods.method_text: Comparative time-efficiency analysis prioritizing staff time as primary metric
methods.verbatim_quote: This discussion, furthermore, focuses on our most limited resource: staff time. As such, the calculations below, which propose dataset size thresholds for various approaches, prioritise staff time required for digitisation.

methods.method_text: Error rate calculation and characterization from quality assurance review
methods.verbatim_quote: Finally, re-examination of four randomly selected maps after fieldwork required 6 h of staff time, including desktop GIS setup, confirmation of feature digitisation, and tabulating errors and error rates.

location.section: 3.1 Project staff time for setup, support, and accuracy-checking

methods.method_text: Map tile assignment to student volunteers
trigger_text: First, participants failed to digitise some assigned maps, leaving noticeable gaps (see Fig. 6).
methods.inference_reasoning: Results mention 'assigned maps' indicating a task allocation method existed, but Methods section contains no description of how maps were assigned to students or how workload was distributed.

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: No description of assignment criteria, workload distribution, or tracking mechanisms
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Cannot evaluate whether assignment strategy affected error rates or efficiency

expected_information_missing: Tracking mechanism for completed vs assigned maps

protocols.protocol_text: FAIMS Mobile customization workflow - 7-stage implementation process
protocols.verbatim_quote: The stages of FAIMS Mobile implementation (Fig. 3) included: (1) project staff modelled the data and workflow to ensure that the final dataset met research needs, (2) a junior software developer worked with project staff to customise the system, (3) project staff defined a spatial reference system (SRS) and imported preprocessed historical maps, (4) volunteers drew a shape (usually a point) wherever they saw a target symbol and (5) volunteers transcribed attributes from the map, (6) project staff exported data using the FAIMS Mobile server, (7) project staff undertook a targeted accuracy-checking exercise.

location.section: 2.4 Design and implementation of the recording system

protocols.protocol_text: Map preprocessing protocol - tiling and pyramid generation for georeferenced GeoTIFFs
protocols.verbatim_quote: Map preparation (tiling, adding pyramids) required about 1.5 h.

location.section: 3.1 Project staff time for setup, support, and accuracy-checking

protocols.protocol_text: Server setup and client device configuration in field
protocols.verbatim_quote: Setup of the server and configuration of the client devices in the field required 3 h from staff.

location.section: 3.1 Project staff time for setup, support, and accuracy-checking

protocols.protocol_text: Student training protocol - minimal training approach
protocols.verbatim_quote: Training and supervision of students took no more than half an hour of staff time across the entire season.
expected_information_missing: Number of students trained each season

location.section: 3.1 Project staff time for setup, support, and accuracy-checking

protocols.protocol_text: Spatial data validation protocol - latitude/longitude population from GPS
protocols.verbatim_quote: For the second season, adding additional validation to ensure population of latitude and longitude from GPS (see 'Recoverable data omissions and incomplete records' below) took 1 h of development from the programmer.

location.section: 3.1 Project staff time for setup, support, and accuracy-checking

protocols.protocol_text: File preparation and transfer protocol - compression, upload, download workflow
protocols.verbatim_quote: Monitoring file compression, upload to the server, and download to devices took an additional 2.5 h.

location.section: 3.1 Project staff time for setup, support, and accuracy-checking

protocols.protocol_text: Point feature digitization procedure - symbol identification and point placement
protocols.verbatim_quote: volunteers drew a shape (usually a point) wherever they saw a target symbol and (5) volunteers transcribed attributes from the map

location.section: 2.4 Design and implementation of the recording system

protocols.protocol_text: Attribute data entry protocol using controlled vocabularies and automated metadata
protocols.verbatim_quote: To support this workflow and make work easier for both project staff and participants, FAIMS Mobile automated a number of tasks and provided necessary capabilities. It applied the spatial reference system, rendered maps in the workspace, provided layer management (including a data entry layer), enforced shape topology, displayed pre-defined controlled vocabularies for attribute terms, recorded creation time and author for each record, maintained a history of all changes to data, applied validation to ensure record completeness, merged data from multiple devices, and exported data in common formats.

location.section: 2.4 Design and implementation of the recording system

protocols.protocol_text: Offline data synchronization protocol - opportunistic sync when network available
protocols.verbatim_quote: Data collection works offline, and can employ as many devices as necessary. It is later synchronised opportunistically, when a network is available.

location.section: 2.3 Using a mobile application for map digitisation

trigger_text: To overcome this problem, in 2010, project staff worked with student volunteers to digitise map features using ArcGIS.

Although we did not maintain detailed volunteer time-on-task records, we know this effort produced a dataset of 915 features and required about 5–7 h of staff training, support, and error-checking over a three-week period (based on our field journals).
protocols.inference_reasoning: Paper mentions desktop GIS digitization was attempted in 2010 with ArcGIS, producing 915 features with 5-7 hours of staff support, but provides no description of the actual digitization procedures, training content, or quality control methods used.

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: No description of ArcGIS workflow, training content, or QC procedures for baseline comparison
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Cannot assess whether comparison is fair given different procedures may have been used

expected_information_missing: Number of volunteers trained vs retained

protocols.protocol_text: Symbol identification and classification criteria for map features
trigger_text: We wished to extract symbols from them that might represent burial or settlement mounds in our study area (see Fig. 2). Such symbols occurred at a high density, averaging about 200 per tile (0.5 per sq km), with counts per tile ranging from about 50 to 400. The mound symbols were moderately obtrusive; some aspects of shape or colour were shared with other map symbols.
Students made only one classification error (a similar symbol mistaken for a benchmark), and no outright false positives.
protocols.inference_reasoning: Paper shows target symbol types in Fig. 2 and mentions 'moderately obtrusive' symbols with shared characteristics, but provides no explicit decision criteria for when students were uncertain about symbol identity. Low classification error rate suggests criteria existed.

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: No description of decision rules for ambiguous symbols or how students resolved uncertainty
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Cannot evaluate whether symbol identification was consistent across volunteers

expected_information_missing: Symbol reference guide provided to students

location.section: 2.1 Archaeological features in Soviet topographic maps

protocols.protocol_text: Performance mitigation protocol - database reset procedure for degraded performance
protocols.verbatim_quote: Deteriorating performance was mitigated by exporting all data and instantiating a new and empty version of the application. Since data structures were identical, aggregation of multiple exports was trivial.

protocols.protocol_text: Data export protocol using FAIMS Mobile server
protocols.verbatim_quote: project staff exported data using the FAIMS Mobile server

location.section: 2.4 Design and implementation of the recording system

protocols.verbatim_quote: Finally, re-examination of four randomly selected maps after fieldwork required 6 h of staff time, including desktop GIS setup, confirmation of feature digitisation, and tabulating errors and error rates.
expected_information_missing: Desktop GIS software used for verification
